citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There were 2 bottles of oral medications (dewormers) in the middle building that had no expiration dates and 1 other
medication (secnidazole) was expired (4/23). Expired medications do not ensure that the medications are effective at
treating disease or illness and the health of the animal may suffer. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must ensure that expired medications are removed from
the facility.
Correction date: 3 November 2023 (Removed from facility during inspection)

In the back row of enclosures behind the middle building, the 2nd enclosure from the north end had a large gap between
the shelter and the 2x4 welded wire panel wall. The enclosed dog was able to place her leg through this gap and almost
placed her head through the gap. The gap was 4-5 inches wide and about 16 inches high. Dogs can become injured by
pushing parts of their body through the gaps and then pulling back quickly. They can also become trapped if they cannot
remove their head from the gap. Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally
sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and
restrict other animals from entering. The licensee must ensure that there are no gaps that can cause injury to the dogs.
Correction date: 3 November 2023

On the east side of the Big Building, one of the outside pens had a sheet of metal at the end of the pen that had sharp
edges on it. The 6 enclosed dogs gather at this end of the enclosure and could become injured from the sharp metal. Any
surface that comes in contact with dogs must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that might injure the animals. The
metal must be replaced or repaired to prevent injury to the dogs.
Correction date: 5 November 2023

Most of the inside enclosures of the Middle Building were excessively dirty. On the left side the 3rd and 4th pen had
excessive feces and other grime and brown material on the floor. In the 4th enclosure, the amount of feces made it
difficult for the dogs to avoid stepping in the feces. Each of these pens contained a female dog with young puppies. On
the right side 2 pens had excessive grime on the exposed wood of the dog door frame. Feces, dirt, and grime can harbor
organisms that can affect the health of the dogs. The licensee must spot clean the feces daily ensure that cleaning and
sanitization are done as frequently as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces, to prevent soiling of the
dogs, and to reduce disease hazards.
Correction date: 3 November 2023

In an outdoor enclosure containing 1 Bulldog, the shelter had no bedding material. The temperature at the time of the
inspection was approximately 41 degrees F (data from Weather Channel app on phone). Animals that expend energy to
stay warm may not thrive and have increased risk of sickness. Bedding material is necessary to protect the dogs from the
cold temperatures. Shelters in outdoor facilities for dogs must contain clean, dry, bedding material if the ambient
temperature is below 50 °F (10 °C). Additional clean, dry bedding is required when the temperature is 35 °F (1.7 °C) or
lower.
Correction date: 3 November (Corrected during inspection)

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Inside the building one of the enclosures has a female Boxer with young puppies (approximately 10 days old). There was
an excessive amount of flies in this enclosure, including numerous dead flies. Flies can cause contamination to the food
and water and irritation to the dogs by biting them. An effective program for the control of insects, external parasites
affecting dogs, and birds and mammals that are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health
and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
Correction date: 4 November 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There were 2 bottles of oral medications (dewormers) in the middle building that had no expiration dates and 1 other 
medication (secnidazole) was expired (4/23). Expired medications do not ensure that the medications are effective at 
treating disease or illness and the health of the animal may suffer. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must ensure that expired medications are removed from 
the facility. 
Correction date: 3 November 2023 (Removed from facility during inspection) 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In the back row of enclosures behind the middle building, the 2nd enclosure from the north end had a large gap between 
the shelter and the 2x4 welded wire panel wall. The enclosed dog was able to place her leg through this gap and almost 
placed her head through the gap. The gap was 4-5 inches wide and about 16 inches high. Dogs can become injured by 
pushing parts of their body through the gaps and then pulling back quickly. They can also become trapped if they cannot 
remove their head from the gap. Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally 
sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and 
restrict other animals from entering. The licensee must ensure that there are no gaps that can cause injury to the dogs. 
 
Correction date: 3 November 2023 
3.1(c)(1)(ii) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
On the east side of the Big Building, one of the outside pens had a sheet of metal at the end of the pen that had sharp 
edges on it. The 6 enclosed dogs gather at this end of the enclosure and could become injured from the sharp metal. Any 
surface that comes in contact with dogs must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that might injure the animals. The 
metal must be replaced or repaired to prevent injury to the dogs. 
 
Correction date: 5 November 2023

3.1(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Most of the inside enclosures of the Middle Building were excessively dirty. On the left side the 3rd and 4th pen had 
excessive feces and other grime and brown material on the floor. In the 4th enclosure, the amount of feces made it 
difficult for the dogs to avoid stepping in the feces. Each of these pens contained a female dog with young puppies. On 
the right side 2 pens had excessive grime on the exposed wood of the dog door frame. Feces, dirt, and grime can harbor 
organisms that can affect the health of the dogs. The licensee must spot clean the feces daily ensure that cleaning and 
sanitization are done as frequently as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces, to prevent soiling of the 
dogs, and to reduce disease hazards. 
 
Correction date: 3 November 2023 
3.4(b)(4) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
In an outdoor enclosure containing 1 Bulldog, the shelter had no bedding material. The temperature at the time of the 
inspection was approximately 41 degrees F (data from Weather Channel app on phone). Animals that expend energy to 
stay warm may not thrive and have increased risk of sickness. Bedding material is necessary to protect the dogs from the 
cold temperatures. Shelters in outdoor facilities for dogs must contain clean, dry, bedding material if the ambient 
temperature is below 50 °F (10 °C). Additional clean, dry bedding is required when the temperature is 35 °F (1.7 °C) or 
lower. 
 
Correction date: 3 November (Corrected during inspection) 
3.11(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Inside the building one of the enclosures has a female Boxer with young puppies (approximately 10 days old). There was 
an excessive amount of flies in this enclosure, including numerous dead flies. Flies can cause contamination to the food 
and water and irritation to the dogs by biting them. An effective program for the control of insects, external parasites 
affecting dogs, and birds and mammals that are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health 
and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.  
 
Correction date: 4 November 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
